section.text: In this analysis, we will be looking at the first few bars of Auld Lang Syne, a traditional Scottish ballad.
First, we must determine the key. Since the key signature contains one flat, we have two possibilities: F major or D minor.
The first chord contains an F, A, and C - an F major triad. Since this is I in F Major, we are most likely in that key.
The next bar contains only F's, A's, and C's - F major triads. Thus, all four chords are I. Since we would be repeating an analysis symbol, there is no need to write it again.
The first chord of the next bar contains C, C, E, and G - a C major triad. Thus, it is a V chord.
The second chord contains a C, C, D, and F - which is just plain weird. Let's skip it for now.
The third chord is a duplicate of the first.
The fourth chord contains a C, Bb, E, and A. Again, this doesn't fit nicely into a triad. We will skip this one too.
The next bar contains only F's, A's, and C's. Again, all four chords are I chords.
The final bar contains a Bb, Bb, F, and D - a Bb major triad. Thus, it is a IV chord.
Let's go back and analyze the sections that we skipped.
If we consider nonharmonic notes, the first skipped section can be analyze as containing two auxiliary notes.
Before proceeding to the second section, there is one piece of information that you should know:
When voicing a seventh chord, composers sometimes leave out the fifth.
Armed with this knowledge, let's reexamine the mystery chord.
The bottom three notes are the root, third, and seventh of a C dominant seventh chord. Only the G (the fifth) is missing.
The A can now be analyzed as a nonharmonic note. Since it it approached by step and then leaps, it is an echappé.
This analysis is reinforced by the fact that V chords commonly resolve to I.
Listen to the above bars of Auld Lang Syne.
